content.description:
Bad Luck and Good Dreams is the bolted mixed variation to the first pitch of Good Luck and Bad Dreams when the first pitch ice isn't in.

Climb the obvious bolt line clipping 5 bolts and then either transition to the ice if it's there around the 6th bolt in the roof, or alternatively cut right to surmount the roof and then traverse back left onto thin ice and the bolted anchor above.

At the base of the first pitch of Good Luck and Bad Dreams. See that entry for approach beta.
6 quickdraws and a couple of stubbies. Bolted anchor.

climbs.name: Crescent Falls
climbs.fa: Greg Grant and Cyril Shokoples, March 1981

content.description:
Crescent Falls is fun, easily accessible, top ropeable and has virtually no approach. What more could you want?

Walk around the viewing platform build an ice anchor and rappel down to the bottom. Watch out for thin ice, do not rappel down the middle of the falls as it will likely be open water or thin ice which will not support you. A single 60m will  get you to the bottom from the viewing platform.

Pick your line and have fun.


Crescent Falls turn off is 72km from the Saskatchewan Crossing on the Icefields Parkway. From the signed turn off for Crescent Falls drive 6km down the road to a parking lot with a gated road heading downhill.

Walk downhill for less than 5 minutes to the viewing platform with the falls below you.

Standard ice rack.

2 pitches up a very cool slot canyon

Walk up James Creek, navigating the ropes course along the way. Break left at the fork
bolted anchors

This climb doesn't form often, but when it does it should not missed. Several mixed pitches lead to a spectacular final ice pitch. 

P1 - Start in a corner about 15M right of the ice pitch above. Climb up 20M and traverse left on ledge to a bolt anchor. ~35M, M5+

P2 - Climb straight up corner crack about 15M to a roof crux with bolt. Another 15-20M leads to a bolt belay just left of a large tree, belay here or head straight to belay left of ice chimney. ~35M, M6+

P3 - Assuming belaying P2 top near tree, head up verglas ledges up and right until able to traverse left under ice chimney to belay under roof. 15-20M

P4 - Head up into wild ice chimney and continue up fatter ice to tree at top, an incredible pitch. 60m, WI5-

Descend P4 in two 30M raps due to rope drag. A better option would probably be for someone to sling a large tree up and left from ice top out and rap directly to P4 belay. 



Drive about 30km east of Saskatchewan Crossing on Hwy 11 and park in pull off to Cavalcade campsite, or on the other side of the hwy a little closer to the Crossing. The climb is easily visible. Walk directly up to it, approach takes about 90 minutes. This area has many decorated ceremonial grounds that should be bypassed on the approach. 

Single rack 0.3 to 3.0. 10-12 ice screws with several stubbies. Two 60M ropes.

Good Luck and Bad Dreams is an adventurous classic with a bit of everything. Not too far from the road it is possible to climb it in half a day and still get on another route in the area in the afternoon. P1 (WI4, 15m): Climb a steep initial curtain on likely bad ice to a bolted anchor on the right a few meters above the lip of the curtain. Alternatively if the ice isn't touching down (which it likely won't be) climb the mixed route Bad Luck and Good Dreams (M6+) on the right and gain the P1 anchor. P2 (WI2, 50m): Climb easy rambling ice (one bolt 5 meters on the right above the P1 anchor if the ice is too thin to protect) to a steep snow ledge with a bolted anchor down low on the left side, around the wide corner before the P3 ice starts. You might have to dig for the bolts in the snow. P3 (WI4, 60m): The money pitch, climb 50 meters of fun WI4 ice up to another snow ledge and build a v thread anchor. P4 (WI3, 15m): Finish with two small ice steps separated by a bit of snow to another v thread anchor. Descent: Make one small rappel from top of P4 to top of P3, then a v thread rappel from top of P3 to bolts at top of P2. One 65 meter rappel gets you down from P2 to the ground, however you need double 70s to make it. Park at the Coral Creek White Goat Staging Area, immediately north of the highway bridge going over the Cline River. The upper pitches of the climb are easily visible from the highway.

Follow a trail for the Mt. Stelfox Via Ferrata initially and then continue traversing up and along gullies working your way towards the climb via the path of least resistance.

30 minutes to an hour depending on conditions. Standard ice rack, a smaller cam would be helpful on the first pitch if using the bolts but there isn't enough ice to follow the bolt line fully.

Classic climb in a very cool location and with beautiful views of Abrahams Lake. The climb consists of the 60m WI4 pitch followed by a 50m steep and sustained WI5 pillar. The third pitch is a 30m WI3 with a bolt station on top (to climbers right). First ascent of Kitty Hawk was accomplished in 1980 as a roped solo following several attempts which reportedly involved a giant whipper, rescue, and 26 stitches. From Saskatchewan Crossing drive ~38km along Dave Thompson Highway (Hwy 11). The climb will be to your left (north) and is easily recognizable from the highway. Park in an obvious pull out in front of the climb.

To reach the climb, head straight for it through the woods. Once through the woods, locate the gully leading to the base of the ice. The gully, which is initially wide (we chose the right bank to ascend), quickly narrows and fills with WI2-3 ice steps. When we did it, the icy sections was filled with powdery waist deep snow. In lean snow conditions it may be necessary to pitch it out. Ice screws

A short steep section leads into easier ice, belay on a tree to the right

50m before End /of The Line
tree anchor

Nice moderate route close to the road. A worthy alternative to nearby Kitty Hawk if the latter is crowded. 
  
 The last pitch is visible from the road. Park well to the side of the road and hike in to the route. Allow a half-hour for the approach to the base of the route. Without much snow cover the approach through the woods can be a bit of a slog over loose rock. 
  
 P1. Up to WI3 with possibly some M-easy moves to surmount a short 85 degree section (pitch crux) near the end of the pitch. Pitch is full 60 meters. 
  
 P2. Short (50 feet) pitch on thicker but likely wetter ice. Belay station (cord slung around tree) can be found in situ. 
  
 P3. The crux pitch (and really the only reason to get on this route). 50 meters of WI4 ice. 
  
 Rap on natural anchors.

Screws. Natural anchors easy to find for rappels.

climbs.name: Pure Energy
climbs.fa: Len Babiuk, Morgan Neff & Cyril Shokoples March 1989

content.description:
A consistently forming and classic line, Pure Energy climbs the main flow found within the Cline River Gallery. A variety of lines are possible and one can access the route from the top by carefully walking down the low angle ice from above until at the lip of the climb.  Park at the Pinto Lake Staging Area (52.16735545448509, -116.4784549473152) and head to the back of the large gravel pit. Walk up out of the pit on a small trail which merges with a much larger main trail that goes through a few campsites and continues West along the south side of the Cline River bank. Stay left at the first junction, and continue following the clearly marked trail for about 20 minutes until the ice is obvious in front of you.

From the viewpoint where you can see the ice, follow the trail for another hundred meters or so, cross a small gully with some ice in it on the right, walk along an exposed cliffside and then drop down a dry gully to access the ice from the bottom up, or keep walking a bit further to access from the top down. Standard ice rack.

Splashdown A & B are technically two different ice flows separated by rock in between. Both feature some steep climbing of varying ice quality directly above the flowing and usually open and deep river. Not a great lead unless the river is frozen solid below you or you have some other plan to not drop your ropes (and belayer for that matter) into the river. Great for TR laps with a belay set up from above. 



Just upstream from Pure Energy, Splashdown A is visible from the riverbed if you walk downstream from Pure Energy. See Pure Energy entry for description of approach and where to park.

Standard ice rack.

climbs.name: Two O'Clock Falls
climbs.fa: Colin Ferguson, Rob Long, Ross McGeachy, 1977

content.description:
An fun, easy afternoon 
 P1 WI3 Short curtain to a screw belay 
 P2 WI2-3 Another short curtain to a screw belay 
 P3 WI1-2 Move the belay up low-angle ice 
 P4 WI2-3 Climb the final step to the trees 
  
 Rap off trees on either side

27.4km east of Saskatchewan Crossing there is a parking area on the right. Cross the road to a gate, go right along the fence inside the gate, then follow the trail left into the forest. You will run across some ceremonial grounds. Head around them trending right until you reach a path leaving the clearing up towards the climb.
Screws

A fun mixed route that is relatively close to the road and is well protected. As with many mixed routes, it can vary greatly from year to year. Sometimes you can catch it fat so the first pitch, which usually requires rock gear, is all ice and requires nothing but screws. The description that follows is from the FA account. P1: 40m, M7-. Follow thin ice to an overhanging corner, pull up left onto a rock step, then follow steep ice to a 2-bolt belay on the left side of a comfortable ledge. P2: 37m, M7-. Dry tool up and right past 7 bolts to a steep ice curtain, then easy ice to the top. Belay from screws and or v-thread. Unicorn starts 10m left of Kitty Hawk. To reach the climb, head straight for it through the woods. Once through the woods, locate the gully leading to the base of the ice. The gully, which is initially wide (we chose the right bank to ascend), quickly narrows and fills with WI2-3 ice steps. When we did it, the icy sections was filled with powdery waist deep snow. In lean snow conditions it may be necessary to pitch it out.

The base of these routes can be crowded, and a high hazard zone for falling ice if there are climbers above on either route. You SHOULD NOT begin climbing either of these routes until parties ahead of you are down. You need to get up earlier next time! A standard mixed rack: set of stoppers, C3’s, and C4’s to #3, as well as draws for bolts. Two-rope rappel from a v-thread at the top.

The David Thompson Corridor is a less frequented area of the Rockies containing some amazing ice routes without the crowds. It also generally receives less snow making for easier travel when the snowpack is deeper elsewhere.

This area is for all the climbs between Saskatchewan Crossing and Nordegg.
